subject: OS-7931 ::refstr would be useful OS-7932 ::ps -s could show service FMRIs OS-7934 ptree could show service FMRIs OS-3513 ptools should see more process arguments Reviewed by: Jerry Jelinek <jerry.jelinek@joyent.com> Reviewed by: Jason King <jason.king@joy

Patch Set 11:

I added testing notes to each of the bugs as relevant
Patch Set 12: Integration-Approval+1
Uploaded patch set 13: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully merged by John Levon
You could do `sizeof ("svc:/") - 1` instead of strlen() to get a compile-time constant.
Done

I think L359-367 are both stripping any leading 'svc:/' as well as any trailing ':default' in the firm.  Is that correct? I'm fairly sure on the stripping of the ':default', but the stripping of the leading 'svc:/' seems a bit more subtle. Maybe a small comment clarifying what's going on?
Done
I'm not sure which of the 4 bugs listed in the commit msg this is related to -- this isn't mdb, ptree(1), or ps(1).  Is there a bug missing in the commit msg?
I updated OS-3513 bug title
Not this bug, but it seems like we'd probably want something like `proc_get_cmdline` in libproc(3LIB) analogous to `proc_get_psinfo` to do this at some point.
Yeah, that would be kind of nice.
Are you guaranteed one of these chars in the command string, or should you check for NULL before you assign?
I don't know how I managed to lose this check, it is indeed broken. I also realised I missed checking ps -o comm from my set of tests. thanks.
Nit: scrsize != 0
Done
Should you explicitly set p->svc_fmri to NULL before you return here?
It's not necessary - all paths already have it initialized to NULL already (and we only call this func conditionally anyway, so it wouldn't help if !sflag)
It looks like you should free(psvc) here.
yep, thanks!
Should we add an VERIFY(MUTEX_HELD(&p->p_lock)) here?  Similar functions seem to do this.  What about VERIFY((p->p_proc_flag & P_PR_LOCK)) like what's done at the end of the function?

I can add the first, though in most cases it's covered by the exit on :132

Re the p_proc_flag - that's checking that we still have that flag set even though we dropped and re-acquired p_lock, so it doesn't make sense at the head of the function.
